displayed_text: Family Member: So he’ll go downstairs and get his blood drawn. Doctor: Yes. All right. So let me make a copy of this though for you for your records. Family Member: We’re very thankful for meeting you. And how thorough you are. And how comfortable, you make you know, it makes me feel comfortable. Doctor: Thank you. Thank you. I always tell me I'm not happy that we met under the circumstances- Patient: Yes. Doctor: - but try make the best of it. Family Member: Yes, yes. And your knowledge you know. You have so much knowledge, you know, different trials and medicines Doctor: You'll help me, you know my family is not in medicine. Family Member: Oh really? Doctor: But sometimes I get accused of speaking in too much medical lingo. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So if you don't, because a lot of my friends are doctors obviously.

Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to –

Family Member: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us. Doctor: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -and give you a copy of the consent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But once we found out, she will be in touch. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: To let you know what we’re going to do. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, if you’ll excuse me one second, I’ll ask one colleague a question. I’ll be right with you. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: The enzalutamide, what you were saying- Family Member: Let him, let him, let him ask a colleague a question. He’ll be right back. Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it? Patient: Well, huh, a doctor from Johns Hopkins two weeks ago worked on a girl, gave her this medicine, and everything disappeared. It’s in the paper. Doctor: But she didn’t have prostate cancer. Family Member: Right. (Laughs) Patient: All right. Cancer is cancer. Family Member: He’s seen something on TV. Patient: No. It was in the paper and TV.

Patient: Now see, I have, I have to, I have to always sit, I have to always sit down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know, because I be fatigued. Doctor: I see. Not a problem. Patient: You know what I’m saying? And, that, that’s the only problem (XXX) Doctor: I’ll give you a script take it over to Vincent’s or whatever and see what they say. Patient: I can’t talk. Like somebody’s stoppin’ and be talkin’ to me. But, let’s go walk up so ‘cuz I can’t stand up that long. Doctor: I see. Patient: And, also, I’ll be out of breath and then my legs Doctor: Yeah, Okay. Patient: get weak. I can, um, I’m all for the standing and talk, bro, that we are gonna talk, let’s sit down. Doctor: So, what do you want to do? Do you want to take a break from the chemotherapy?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I’ll tell him about you though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But he’s coming May ninth. Patient: Alright. Don’t you leave me yet man. (Laughs) Doctor: I hope so too. He’s the man right? Patient: Yeah, yeah you’re the man but you have more grey. <____> refer me to you. Doctor: I hope that when I see you next time I will be able to give you news that yes he’s coming. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And so, so we do this blood test all the way up until September. Doctor: Oh we’re still gonna do the blood test. I still get blood tests.

Patient: I got that did. Doctor: Yep. See slowly we’re fixing you up. Patient: Yeah I’ll be good in no time. Okay. (laughs) Doctor: The only thing not behaving is your prostate number though. Patient: That’s because I didn’t get it. After three months it was four and a half. That’s what happened. Doctor: Yeah. You still shouldn’t be sort of rising. Patient: I shouldn’t go… Doctor: So I think what we’re gonna do because it’s been a while since we checked your bone scan and your CAT scan. Patient: Hmm hmmm. Doctor: Because remember we had those lymph nodes, we tried to get at those lymph nodes and this way we just want to recheck again because your last set of scans was twenty sixteen. So it’s probably a good idea to look Patient: Hmm yeah. Doctor: So W____’s gonna write out the paperwork for the bone scan.

Family Member: So all the other tests that he’s had- Doctor: Mm, hmm. Family Member: — the ultrasound, all that stuff, the x-ray, I mean everything’s good? Doctor: Okay, I mean good in the sense there’s nothing to do other than change the treatment and move on to the next level. Family Member: It hasn’t spread to anything else. Doctor: Nothing else. I mean it’s just bone. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Organs are good. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Okay, okay still got diabetes to worry about, not the cancer. Patient: So bone as in spine or is it now in Doctor: Yeah, spine as in spine and pelvis. So it’s right here. Healthcare Professional: So quit climbing ladders and falling.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once once you decide, if you decide to participate in the clinical trial, then you will come back and there will be a screening visit. Or uh we’re going to go through all the eligibility with you. Do a physical exam, go through a CT scan and a bone scan. It’s a little bit more involved. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um if you decide the trial doesn’t sound right for you, then I am going to start the standard Xtandi and we’re going to send it up, send the medication to you house hopefully after its reimbursed. Patient: Right. Patient: No. Uh uh. Oh, you all gon’ call me today or tomorrow about the blood work, right? Doctor: As soon as I have your PSA test which either be uh late this afternoon or early tomorrow morning, I’m going to call you at the (doc recites patient’s telephone number) Patient: Right. Doctor: Phone number. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Is is that the best for you? Patient: Yes. Mhm.

Patient: So I should be good for three weeks anyway? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I need some kind of release from you for our HR Department saying it’s okay for me to work. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: As long as I’m feeling up to it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. We can fill one of those papers out. Yeah. Patient: Okay. What else did I have? Doctor: If you need to go upstairs, you can. Patient: You can go up and take care of it. Doctor: You’ve got to take care of business. Go ahead. You know we’ll be here a while. (Laughs) Family Member: I may have to go sign an order.

Patient: Uh those pills they didn’t do anything. Doctor: Okay well don’t stop taking ‘em because… Patient: Well I took ‘em. Doctor: Oh you so you finished taking them and you ran out of them is what you mean? Patient: Yeah, yeah I took ‘em. Doctor: You should have some refills. Did you look at the bottle? Patient: Well you know I ordered some more yeah. Doctor: Oh you got a refill. Patient: I haven’t been doing better. Doctor: Okay but stay with them because what it does it’s not gonna be immediate, it allows the blood flow to go into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And take it uh like twice a week.

Patient: Well I guess... Family Member: How long would we have to do that for that just out of curiosity? Doctor: It’s a, I’ll give you the exact… Doctor: Yeah but it’s more for the monitoring and because it’s a phase one trial it’s a little bit more closer monitoring. At least the first few weeks. After that it goes down to once a month once we sort of get the comfort level that you’re tolerating it okay, we know all the PKs and the blood level things are done, then it becomes much easier schedule. Family Member: What are the, how often are you talking about? A couple times a week or? Doctor: Well the first few weeks it will be about once a week or so or once every couple of weeks after a little while. And then after the first couple of months it goes to like I said once every four weeks. Family Member: Kind of like we started with this one. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because the first couple of weeks I came down here… Doctor: It was more intense and then it… Family Member: In the beginning. Doctor: And then it smooths off once.

Patient: What would you do to accommodate me with the seizure other than dialing nine one one? Doctor: Nothing. You have to let the seizure run out. Patient: I can’t (talking over doctor) Doctor: You can’t do… Patient: I still be able to breath and everything? Doctor: Yes, but it’s scary actually most times for people standing next to you, not you, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you probably won’t even know what’s going on. Patient: But see doc, say between her and the wife, they’re the ninety percent around me all the time Doctor: Right, right. Patient: -and the reason why I say this. Family Member: I know what to do if you have a seizure because I’ve had a seizure – Patient: And, so, so..

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in the past you know we talked about the backup plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: What will we do - the day that I say hey, you know this isn’t working or you say I don’t want to do this anymore. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, We checked, you know, the one, the new therapy setting still where you live at. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Some of it is sometimes that blood test that’s fluctuating could be better. Usually it doesn’t. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we would definitely have to repeat that again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because if you’re seven and remained positive, then you’re eligible for one study versus another study. Patient: Oh.

Patient: It varies. Like the night before I didn’t wake up until like four and then some nights it might be every two hours or couple of hours. Doctor: hm mmm, yep, yeah, Do you feel like you empty when you pee Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or do you feel there’s a little more in there? Patient: There’s more because you go ahead and pee the full stream then you stop then you, it’s bogged down. Doctor: Yep, Yep, So, do me a favor. Like after seven p.m. at night don’t drink fluid; Patient: Okay. Doctor: don’t drink water, don’t drink tea, don’t drink coffee, don’t drink juice, don’t drink milk, don’t drink anything. After dinner, just done. One, that will allow you to sleep because I think your prostate is acting up, it’s too big which means it’s blocking the way of the pee and then what happens is you pee but there’s stuff left over but your body doesn’t know it until just a little bit more accumulates in there and also your bladder is like oh, I was this full and now I’m this full, okay, I got to pee again and when you’re laying down you pee a lot easier because then your whole body is trying to recalibrate and what’s happening. So, at that point you got to pee some more. So, if you give it less reason to pee which means you don’t have enough fluid on board then you won’t pee because there’s not fluid to put through. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you do me a favor and do that. I’ll work on getting your CAT scan and your bone scan set up and then we’ll figure out the next step. My thinking is that it probably - I’m going to shoot for the ah vaccine because once that’s done we don’t go back to it and then we just sort of put that and say done and then we move on to the other stuff. What do you think of that? Because if that sounds okay what takes forever is insurance Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: so if you’re kind of conceptually okay with that then I’m going to have J____, you know J____ who is our nurse, if you don’t know J____, you’re gonna know J____ in a minute. Patient: Is that the one that took the…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian
